class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Column 1 is the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A and Decl. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1 DDMMSS.s. Column 2 provides the plate\u2013MJD\u2013fibre of the spectra. Columns 3 and 4 are the redshifts of the foreground lenses and the background galaxies inferred from the BOSS spectra. Columns 5 and 6 are the coordinates in terms of truncated J2000 R.A and Decl. Column 7 is the BOSS-measured <em>i</em>-band apparent cmodel magnitude within the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1^{^{\\prime \\prime }}$|</span> fibre. Column 8 is the total apparent flux of the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines in units of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{-17}\\, \\mathrm{erg\\, cm^{-2} \\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. Column 9 is the skewness of the emission line profiles.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Column 1 is the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A and Decl. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1 DDMMSS.s. Column 2 provides the plate\u2013MJD\u2013fibre of the spectra. Columns 3 and 4 are the redshifts of the foreground lenses and the background galaxies inferred from the BOSS spectra. Columns 5 and 6 are the coordinates in terms of truncated J2000 R.A and Decl. Column 7 is the BOSS-measured <em>i</em>-band apparent cmodel magnitude within the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1^{^{\\prime \\prime }}$|</span> fibre. Column 8 is the total apparent flux of the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines in units of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{-17}\\, \\mathrm{erg\\, cm^{-2} \\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. Column 9 is the skewness of the emission line profiles.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" China</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-author-correspondence\">\r\n        E-mail: <a href=\"mailto:jcwang@ynao.ac.cn\" target=\"_blank\">jcwang@ynao.ac.cn</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=Jiancheng+Wang\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Wang Jiancheng%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-abs_connect?return_req=no_params&amp;author=Wang,J\">ADS</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>                                    </span>\r\n                                </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Hongtao Liu</a><span class='delimiter'></span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Hongtao Liu\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">Yunnan Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 396 Yangfangwang, Guandu District, Kunming, 650216, P. R. China</div><div class=\"aff\">University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, P. R. China</div><div class=\"aff\">Center for Astronomical Mega-Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 20A Datun Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing, 100012, P. R.       </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div          <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"ww-citation-history-wrap js-article-history st-article-history\">\r\n                    <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down   <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"5116180\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/482/1/313/26151492/sty2708.pdf\">\r\n            <img <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=122983548 id=\"122983548\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">More than 100 galaxy-scale strong gravitational lens systems have been found by searching for the emission lines coming from galaxies with redshifts higher than the lens galaxies. Based on this spectroscopic-selection method, we introduce the deep Residual Networks (ResNet; a kind of deep Convolutional Neural Networks) to search for the galaxy-Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emitter (LAE) lens candidates by recognizing the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines coming from high- redshift galaxies (2 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 3) in the spectra of early-type galaxies (ETGs) at middle redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span> \u223c 0.5). The spectra of the ETGs come from the Data Release 12 (DR12) of the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (SDSS-III). In this paper, we first build a 28 layers ResNet model, and then artificially synthesize 150\u00a0000 training spectra, including 140\u00a0000 spectra without Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines and 10\u00a0000 ones with Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines, to train the networks. After 20 training epochs, we obtain a near-perfect test accuracy at 0.995\u00a04. The corresponding loss is 0.002\u00a08 and the completeness is 93.6\u00a0per\u2009cent. We finally apply our ResNet model to our predictive data with 174 known lens candidates. We obtain 1232 hits including 161 of the 174 known candidates (92.5\u00a0per\u2009cent discovery rate). Apart from the hits found in other works, our ResNet model also find 536 new hits. We then perform several subsequent selections on these 536 hits and present five most believable lens candidates.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: structure&quot;\">galaxies: structure</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=122983550 id=\"122983550\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy-scale strong gravitational lens, which can provide very tight constraints on the projected mass of the lens galaxies, is not only an available probe to study the structures, formation, and evolution of galaxies (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), but also a crucial technique to study cosmology (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Additionally, gravitational lenses could act as natural telescopes and give us magnified views of the background objects, which could help us to study the celestial bodies in the distant universe (e.g. Impellizzeri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Several methods have been used to search for the galaxy-scale strong gravitational lenses. Among them, an efficient one is searching for the arc-like morphological features of strong lens systems (Lenzen, Schindler\u00a0&amp; Scherzer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Horesh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Seidel\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Kubo\u00a0&amp; Dell\u2019Antonio <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). In order to find strong lens systems in a great deal of galaxy images., Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) subtracted the light of the central galaxies using multiband images and then searched for the arc-like shapes in the residual images. Another modified work was done by Joseph et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), who successfully subtracted the light of the foreground galaxies with Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and then searched for gravitational lens features in the residual images. They pointed out that the PCA-based galaxy subtraction algorithm performed better than the traditional model fitting method (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Besides the method of morphological recognition, Warren et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) proposed a spectroscopic-selection technique to search for galaxy\u2013galaxy strong lens systems. This technique identifies lens candidates by looking for compound spectra. Let us use the identified lensing system SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>) as an example to clarify the compound spectra. The foreground galaxy of SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 is an early-type galaxy (ETG, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c 0.6073). Between 3800\u2009\u00c5 and 5000\u2009\u00c5, there is no emission line in the spectrum. However, near 4150\u2009\u00c5, we find a Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> line which comes from a Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emitter (LAE). The LAE is at the redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 2.399 9 and lies close to the line of sight of the foreground ETG. The light from the LAE is deflected by the foreground ETG, and then several images of the background LAE emerge around the foreground galaxy. Further detailed description of the spectroscopic-selection technique can be found in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). In general, this technique identifies lens candidates by searching for the spectra with emission lines from background sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Several galaxy-scale strong lens surveys have been made with the above spectroscopic-selection technique, such as the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the SLACS for the Masses (S4TM; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and the BELLS for the GALaxy-Ly\u03b1 EmitteR sYstems Survey (BELLS GALLERY; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). More than 100 galaxy\u2013galaxy strong gravitational lenses have been found in these surveys. A lot of significant works about the structures, formation, and evolution of ETGs have been done with these lens systems (Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Li et al.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_487_1539342759451\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_487_1539342759451\" data-open=\"bib1_487_1539342759451\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Recently, using a similar technique, Meyer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have found nine secure QSO-Galaxy lens candidates, presenting the potential application of the spectroscopic-selection technique in QSO Lens searching. So far, this spectroscopic-selection technique is one of the most efficient methods. However, the speed of this traditional method is not fast enough, especially in the coming age of the big data in astronomy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, the Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), a kind of machine learning algorithm, have been applied in astronomy. The first application of the CNNs is the spectral classification of the data release 10 (DR10) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). H\u00e1la (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) applied his CNN model on more than 60\u00a0000 spectra of SDSS and yielded a success rate of nearly 95\u00a0per\u2009cent. Their work conclusively proved the great potential of the CNNs in astrophysics. Later, the CNNs have been applied in some other works, such as the morphological classification of SDSS galaxies (Dieleman, Willett\u00a0&amp; Dambre <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the photometric redshift estimates of SDSS galaxies (Hoyle <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and the star/galaxy classification (Kim\u00a0&amp; Brunner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In the field of gravitational lenses, Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Lanusse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have used the CNNs to recognize galaxy-scale strong gravitational lenses based on morphological classification. In Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), they found 761 strong lens candidates in the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) and presented 56 most reliable candidates after manual selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CNNs have not been applied for searching gravitational lens candidates based on the spectroscopic-selection technique. In this paper, we will use the deep Residual Networks (ResNet; one popular model of CNNs) to search for the galaxy-LAE lens candidates in DR12 of SDSS by recognizing the high-redshift (2 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 3) Ly\u03b1 emission lines. LAEs are a kind of young, low-mass galaxies with an extremely high star formation rate. They are important components of the early universe, and critical for studying the formation and evolution of galaxies. Benefited from the magnifying effect, galaxy-LAE lenses can provide us good opportunities to study the LAEs themselves. More importantly, galaxy-LAE lenses can help us to exploit the small-scale dark substructures around the lens galaxies and constrain the slope and normalization of the substructure-mass function (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we provide a brief description of Machine Learning, CNNs, and ResNet. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we talk about how to use ResNet to recognize emission lines that are not from the foreground galaxies themselves. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we present five new gravitational lens candidates found by our ResNet model. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we discuss the advantages and the possible improvement of our strategy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=122983558 id=\"122983558\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 MACHINE LEARNING, CNNS, AND RESNET</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we provide a brief introduction of Machine Learning, CNNs, and ResNet.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983560 id=\"122983560\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 The Machine Learning and Deep learning</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Machine Learning was coined in 1959 by Samue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1959</a>). It is a field of computer science that gives computers the ability to learn from train data and then make predictions on predictive data. Depending on whether there are given \u2018labels\u2019 for the learning systems, Machine Learning is typically classified into two classes, supervised learning and unsupervised learning. For supervised learning, the train data as well as the \u2018labels\u2019 for the train data are given to the learning algorithm. Then the learning algorithm would \u2018learn\u2019 a general rule that maps inputs to outputs. For unsupervised learning, no \u2018labels\u2019 are given, the learning algorithm has to discovery hidden patterns in the train data by itself. The Machine Learning algorithm could be designed to achieve various tasks, such as classification, regression, clustering, density estimation, and so on. The task in our work is in fact a classification task which can be tackled in a supervised way. The train data in our work could be divided into two classes and given different \u2018labels\u2019. Then the learning algorithm could \u2018learn\u2019 from the train data and their \u2018labels\u2019 then produce a model that assigns the inputs to one of the two classes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Deep learning is a kind of Machine Learning with multiple layers to extract the feature of the inputs. Each later layer uses the outputs of the previous layer as inputs. Most deep learning models are based on artificial neural networks (ANNs) which consist of many artificial neurons. Similar with biophysical neurons, the artificial neurons of ANNs can receive inputs, change their states according to the inputs, and then produce outputs depending on their states. If the artificial neurons of deep ANNs can only receive informations from the previous layer and output informations to the next layer, we call this kind of ANNs as deep feedforward neural networks. There are no cycles or loops in these kinds of networks. More detailed information about Deep learning can be found in Lanusse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983563 id=\"122983563\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 The CNNs</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As one of the most popular models of deep learning, recent years, the CNNs have gained a lot of attentions in image recognition, speech recognition, motion analysis, nature language processing, as well as many other researching fields. CNNs are a kind of deep feedforward neural networks and formed by a stack of distinct layers. The layers mainly contain the convolutional layers, the pooling layers and the fully connected layers. Here are some important terminologies of CNNs used in this paper: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Convolutional layers:</em> The convolutional layers apply convolutional operations to the inputs and then pass the results to the next layers. Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> (from the internet, just for illustration) shows a simple convolutional operation. A 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 input image (green) is convolved by a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 convolutional kernel (yellow, also known as convolutional neurons). The result of this convolutional operation is a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 feature map. Simply speaking, the convolutional layers are used to extract different features of the inputs. Usually, there are several convolutional neurons in one feature map. The convolutional neurons are composed of weights and bias which could be written as <strong>{<em>W, b</em>}</strong>. The weights and bias could be trained by the train data.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Pooling layers:</em> The pooling layers are introduced between two convolutional layers (local pooling layers) or before the fully connected layers (global pooling layers) to compress the feature maps and simplify the calculations. There are two common pooling methods, max pooling and average pooling. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (from the internet, just for illustration) shows a max pooling with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 filters. Each filter could find the maximum value of the corresponding local area to represent this local area in order to form a new compressed feature map.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Fully connected layers:</em> The fully connected layers connect every neuron in one layer to every neuron, in another layer to turn all the local feature maps into a global feature map.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Dropout layers:</em> All of the parameters of the weights and bias would occur in the fully connected layers, which probably cause overfitting. One method to reduce the overfitting is to introduce the Dropout layers. During each training process, we can randomly \u2018drop out\u2019 some parameters of <strong>{<em>W, b</em>}</strong> with probability 1\u00a0\u2212 <em>p</em> or keep the parameters with probability <em>p</em>. After a \u2018Dropout\u2019 operation, a reduced network is left and would be gained on data.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Activation function:</em> The Activation function defines the outputs of a neuron given inputs. A neuron receives signals and \u2018activate\u2019 them using Activation function, then output the activated signals to the next neuron. For CNNs, only non-linear Activation functions could be used, because if the Activation functions are linear, there were only linear transformations between two layers, which could reduce the capacity of the networks. Additionally, non-linear Activation functions can limit the outputs to be finite values (Gulcehre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Loss:</em> A Machine Learning model is trained by minimising a given loss that measure the deviation between the predicted values and the real values. The loss function could be defined by the user.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Accuracy and completeness:</em> The accuracy and completeness are used to measure the capacity of a classification model. For example, we have totally <em>m</em> samples, among them, <em>n</em> samples are positive samples, the remain are negative. If <em>i</em> samples are classified as positive by our model, among them, <em>j</em> samples are real positive. Then the accuracy is defined as <em>j</em>/<em>i</em>, the completeness is defined as <em>j</em>/<em>n</em>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Epoch:</em> Epoch is a terminology of Keras<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> used in this work. Keras is a high-level neural networks application programming interface (API), and capable of running on top of TensorFlow,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> CNTK,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> or Theano.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> For Keras, the train dataset would be divided into lots of batches, the networks are updated when a batch is processed. An epoch is an iteration over the entire dataset.</p></li></ul></p>                        <a id=\"122983565\" scrollto-destination=\"122983565\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=Ac6tLeH~nDwJwP-P31oszjjqnkBXuNHtBb3xqKMfj7IVzrPnW1OiZXR3Af0ob9PVwA1JIO1NytHTQgZXcHwxUyVfYjXWkleWpfzF5-P-CtddYZbNNt0MG9q9L~jff8kJTtSmRelXxGWx6CDi39kJc3yay5Q3S1abbHGOMiLA-KP9EXLmWRK3FN9JMzrz7fKlFSImLte8p5WJwWS2yqq963piAUQHZvXeqhbymLEpA1~mPCapXqZCwguJTTupFmTGsjBNLUT0zEEMbbEUJnqx6DxXhLFkLOHmFsI92beSIN5fx39G89oAM~EcLjrp0H7d-D8o0QEFk1rLz0CSyYAg5Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the convolutional layer. A 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 image (green) is convolved by a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 convolutional kernel (yellow). The result of this convolutional operation is a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 feature map. The convolutional kernel moves on the image by 1 stride and then output the convolutional result to the feature map.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983565/sty2708fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983565\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=mVLYiBo9C90BaM9g9tXdg60HHf4WpnxXIZbQYj1kpLS8yXqZe8K20YDWyO0OZDWuJUAIwG8V1lWg9Q-KPps4assep5lSpv6uOSQeB4DSwNaSuVXJ8Jddsr0hQ7uXIYOtGwdXDgY9eH6i86fWszpXa7BugsHHc0M67MQJsI9tYS4UikcD-wORKtfpeW8C-ZnuA98iieJEJQCg-iIbF1rCQtNIO4NCIs6uLfFMFprgD28VbpmI6qZkSsUZJKArdUlGjh-mOVXHDoRlbpCpwKRHXJqXH8YSSFLqYEyVkd1iO6wsSqnzZfH-HrHBNvKXYrfUk0KmHtHOCytK2ScJvUXwpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983565&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the convolutional layer. A 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 image (green) is convolved by a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 convolutional kernel (yellow). The result of this convolutional operation is a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 feature map. The convolutional kernel moves on the image by 1 stride and then output the convolutional result to the feature map.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=Ac6tLeH~nDwJwP-P31oszjjqnkBXuNHtBb3xqKMfj7IVzrPnW1OiZXR3Af0ob9PVwA1JIO1NytHTQgZXcHwxUyVfYjXWkleWpfzF5-P-CtddYZbNNt0MG9q9L~jff8kJTtSmRelXxGWx6CDi39kJc3yay5Q3S1abbHGOMiLA-KP9EXLmWRK3FN9JMzrz7fKlFSImLte8p5WJwWS2yqq963piAUQHZvXeqhbymLEpA1~mPCapXqZCwguJTTupFmTGsjBNLUT0zEEMbbEUJnqx6DxXhLFkLOHmFsI92beSIN5fx39G89oAM~EcLjrp0H7d-D8o0QEFk1rLz0CSyYAg5Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the convolutional layer. A 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 image (green) is convolved by a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 convolutional kernel (yellow). The result of this convolutional operation is a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 feature map. The convolutional kernel moves on the image by 1 stride and then output the convolutional result to the feature map.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983565/sty2708fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983565\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=mVLYiBo9C90BaM9g9tXdg60HHf4WpnxXIZbQYj1kpLS8yXqZe8K20YDWyO0OZDWuJUAIwG8V1lWg9Q-KPps4assep5lSpv6uOSQeB4DSwNaSuVXJ8Jddsr0hQ7uXIYOtGwdXDgY9eH6i86fWszpXa7BugsHHc0M67MQJsI9tYS4UikcD-wORKtfpeW8C-ZnuA98iieJEJQCg-iIbF1rCQtNIO4NCIs6uLfFMFprgD28VbpmI6qZkSsUZJKArdUlGjh-mOVXHDoRlbpCpwKRHXJqXH8YSSFLqYEyVkd1iO6wsSqnzZfH-HrHBNvKXYrfUk0KmHtHOCytK2ScJvUXwpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983565&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the convolutional layer. A 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 image (green) is convolved by a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 convolutional kernel (yellow). The result of this convolutional operation is a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 feature map. The convolutional kernel moves on the image by 1 stride and then output the convolutional result to the feature map.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"122983566\" scrollto-destination=\"122983566\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=Ok97S9m-kA6XwIuCorZ1KJW-tHnOGhnB2VTSX1kzDMDvWbgihAnTLgDxRhzAypSteAVUAyVAAJetI-2BTpRr5iwTvnNVyTDnyx7P35~DPkTqJyXS1oxw9loLeQGygNR-WQiE48eRIDwW-Lh9V0s3YStCkAt5VFuFBUS6WsGRBT1Zj8lwey4Ti-ndS0I3QQ4VADKq6sGQyqTtIb4KltbVJKmaAvy1kBxd-FRV3sDZh5id6SvY3LiaPwWfqNBU5-7xHBpoNC9WyHogs-21kTwV52i5y-ZUCLbisA4zEmP8ai6q6Iti6KdEXOqM546KdrtTnxLYmj8l~Fjb6Bm0lNlWTg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the pooling layer. It is a max pooling layer with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 filters. The filters will find the maximum values of the corresponding local areas and then use the maximum values to represent these local areas to form a new compressed feature map.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983566/sty2708fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983566\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=w7ACV8LsFPQ0Knlui46RRQTiDK-wbNzpw-dbwsbOe8gWNVFCGmm4W29FjAJqrzwz2sHjzZe05Iqq-ZOFGhJ4W1pm4lL7oEm0JQMs-oQAO5JKVmYXHIGGW5ipa53gB5xh5WpqYCH8XehMoGMZpibCPwieIV9cICW0-Tabdu8E27iiSceVkVqVq7dI8yIKazRCnCGpXiUnIM2P6es8dAOmjXygfx7mabVoFCLzgXlIKG3CbqxgUVaeLnp28THhfkGrSUkB15TZoQXlHco3OZUzV~biHmvx-IdGIP0wQasSZWVHgVxdgIZ4iO-EqLoprPqu2et~31nqDBCzId0ihFbYMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983566&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the pooling layer. It is a max pooling layer with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 filters. The filters will find the maximum values of the corresponding local areas and then use the maximum values to represent these local areas to form a new compressed feature map.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=Ok97S9m-kA6XwIuCorZ1KJW-tHnOGhnB2VTSX1kzDMDvWbgihAnTLgDxRhzAypSteAVUAyVAAJetI-2BTpRr5iwTvnNVyTDnyx7P35~DPkTqJyXS1oxw9loLeQGygNR-WQiE48eRIDwW-Lh9V0s3YStCkAt5VFuFBUS6WsGRBT1Zj8lwey4Ti-ndS0I3QQ4VADKq6sGQyqTtIb4KltbVJKmaAvy1kBxd-FRV3sDZh5id6SvY3LiaPwWfqNBU5-7xHBpoNC9WyHogs-21kTwV52i5y-ZUCLbisA4zEmP8ai6q6Iti6KdEXOqM546KdrtTnxLYmj8l~Fjb6Bm0lNlWTg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the pooling layer. It is a max pooling layer with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 filters. The filters will find the maximum values of the corresponding local areas and then use the maximum values to represent these local areas to form a new compressed feature map.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983566/sty2708fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983566\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=w7ACV8LsFPQ0Knlui46RRQTiDK-wbNzpw-dbwsbOe8gWNVFCGmm4W29FjAJqrzwz2sHjzZe05Iqq-ZOFGhJ4W1pm4lL7oEm0JQMs-oQAO5JKVmYXHIGGW5ipa53gB5xh5WpqYCH8XehMoGMZpibCPwieIV9cICW0-Tabdu8E27iiSceVkVqVq7dI8yIKazRCnCGpXiUnIM2P6es8dAOmjXygfx7mabVoFCLzgXlIKG3CbqxgUVaeLnp28THhfkGrSUkB15TZoQXlHco3OZUzV~biHmvx-IdGIP0wQasSZWVHgVxdgIZ4iO-EqLoprPqu2et~31nqDBCzId0ihFbYMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983566&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the pooling layer. It is a max pooling layer with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 filters. The filters will find the maximum values of the corresponding local areas and then use the maximum values to represent these local areas to form a new compressed feature map.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The entire training process of a CNN model is as follow: (1) Initialize the weights and bias <strong>{<em>W, b</em>}</strong> of the CNN model. (2) The inputs are convolved by the convolutional layers, resulting in some feature maps. Then the feature maps are compressed by the pooling layers. Repeat this process if necessary. (3) At the end of the networks, the fully connected layers are used to obtain the predicted values. (4) Calculate the deviation between the predicted values and the input values. If the deviation is bigger than our expectation, update the weights and bias <strong>{<em>W, b</em>}</strong> according to the deviation and retrain the networks. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (from the internet, just for illustration) shows a simple but complete CNN model with two convolutional layers, two pooling layers and one fully connected layer. The input image is convolved by three convolutional kernels, resulting in three feature maps. These three feature maps are then compressed by a pooling layer. Next, the outputs of the pooling layer are processed by another convolutional layer and pooling layer. Finally, a fully connected layer is used to turn the local feature maps into a global feature map and output the prectived values.</p>                        <a id=\"122983568\" scrollto-destination=\"122983568\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img convolutional layers, two pooling layers, and one fully connected layers.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=MvEdYkLJi69sAoD5Safdpcu885pozeIJpX84zaLClMS~lt6I4tDLb7Jz1juuX3BCeuvjSoBOIBmzEG1MSSyT8VuMvAQtoURg5uSRdSIqYewBV9C6lgsXt5r1EbNwnrME-UMJpxu-4UxE8q76S0e4HeQatvOHEPQQ-6WW9L71ZCQ29yRBXdbbCk9WgBn35lqqPfhooyESaahPut1n5vInLpU0k5PU4MJ1gUwQxYfB1oH0D-n-avVR3bLP57cG37z4oClwJ5~8ZYPTia08XSMsiyItLhm6Pa5m4KW2YXw7L6iptRlZwJn45rJM6JDozrUxl-ukzv7x5OfVekrkwxOaQw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A simple but complete CNN model with two convolutional layers, two pooling layers, and one fully connected layers.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983568/sty2708fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983568\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=RPLAmiwDjqGukthvuqiH27oVZqq5-1V0ESxHwPdR6L1cV6PzhUxwKNMnXjL6G3XbI64PNhwxfxkn1UkhKC8A-Qo8YcXyoTqRyURHYwvdcdR0BT7C~bEJp2WtSAoH95pR60NLCVQFeZ700w6euKxVeAyCrqEAZ8hNIsWmpAWoKlBo5wJZTImnsPJFXjQlMTTfpzLMMu1wkFOXbTYdCwB7J~Y6yhrBZ3mF462XMfdD8RGBH0l0N27Ih-uaE7~m5nsONY3J2Z8wuy5SjhFPODGLFMcNc29MXI6VFe1zQ06d-8oDXkymm-URG5Xtw6i7OSUMaM6ktpL2CjLSOppXW2QILw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983568&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A simple but complete CNN model with two convolutional layers, two pooling layers, and one fully connected layers.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983569 id=\"122983569\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 The ResNet</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Many evidences show that the network depth is very important for the classification and regression tasks. Theoretically, the training results of the networks should become better as the layers become deeper. However, for deep networks, a \u2018degradation\u2019 problem would occur when they start converging. With the increase of network depth, the accuracy gets saturated and then degrades rapidly (He et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which is not caused by overfitting. That\u2019s why many popular CNN models have only a few layers (e.g. five layers in LeNet, seven layers in AlexNet; Lecun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Krizhevsky, Sutskever\u00a0&amp; Hinton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). In order to overcome the degradation of the accuracy of deep networks, He et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) proposed a new CNN model: the deep Residual Networks.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">ResNet assumes that it is easier to optimize the residual mapping than to optimize the origin, unreferenced mapping. Denoting the desired underlying mapping as <em>H</em>(<em>x</em>) which would be fitted by a few stacked layers. <em>x</em> is the inputs of the first layer. ResNet lets the stacked layers to fit the residual mapping of <em>F</em>(<em>x</em>) \u2254 <em>H</em>(<em>x</em>) \u2212 <em>x</em>. Then the original mapping <em>H</em>(<em>x</em>) becomes <em>F</em>(<em>x</em>) + <em>x</em>, and it could be realized by the networks with \u2018shortcut connections\u2019 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The \u2018shortcut connections\u2019 simply perform the identity mapping, then skip one or more layers and add their outputs to the outputs of the stacked layers. In He et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the authors explained that \u2018With the residual learning reformulation, if identity mappings are optimal, the solvers may simply drive the weights of the multiple nonlinear layers toward zero to approach identity mappings.\u2019</p>                        <a id=\"122983572\" scrollto-destination=\"122983572\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=cLGIGzQIwwa2X4mYjG2Q4oooElZuu1wuVQ4GcHPvbTa-rjRd~iqtDH~PK5C6B2wnGyE3RWFM9eCuQptBM9w1rCA83lOUqm70jDJg~Ys8JInRJ3yODk-fQ15Jax7UNmDZAb2BosL1tiuBaMYy2HqgJBERSCs8hAQnRPPebHdAwQraxvchpvt7BmrChsQ5xuLykCdtvE1mjv4H5r-YmFHB-VWNF0JOl08qKFgoprpynkKSuevUMN3dGZAlO84E842tkF5qq33N4KiJ8wiJTgHkc--jt~SDeSTVkGuHiZqQnTr599vq17zkVFab4xBF6Ui3TXz8y6UGzFSb8Xzxu-oLjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual learning: a building block with a shortcut connection (He et\u00a0al. 2015). The weight layers are the assemble of several convolutional layers and other necessary layers. Relu (Xavier et\u00a0al. 2011) is one kind of Activation Function.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983572/sty2708fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983572\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=QxwsolBxl1AesxI-Q9RP9UOtjBccABkZHsl-RxXOCdynB6WMrISgUTySrgc-CNP5WHQke28GlB6UgBPKo2VI5bkxKVlsCjjYlyNlenipMFAvPBuFuBmaEWqnp4an9A3dXVFDvg-yTQGNc7PLCGq0qDsTCK1PedX1kZlKGsDLwTYWeUpHXL6QW3-dNqsEkv1eADb~ULjndGl8q8TP0bt-L4ck5kga1RYWMxCFbmD0E-ZKJ~IYTtiJuwBzUe~VYBzMvd8vS-myCZZFA9jXu4zlEs~aB9N0K0ojXOVo6T4wLM3~7vsY84NM3bbD7pW4ktQHmz~Rg~MWBQzR9c9QjqHvaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983572&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual learning: a building block with a shortcut connection (He et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The weight layers are the assemble of several convolutional layers and other necessary layers. Relu (Xavier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is one kind of Activation Function.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=cLGIGzQIwwa2X4mYjG2Q4oooElZuu1wuVQ4GcHPvbTa-rjRd~iqtDH~PK5C6B2wnGyE3RWFM9eCuQptBM9w1rCA83lOUqm70jDJg~Ys8JInRJ3yODk-fQ15Jax7UNmDZAb2BosL1tiuBaMYy2HqgJBERSCs8hAQnRPPebHdAwQraxvchpvt7BmrChsQ5xuLykCdtvE1mjv4H5r-YmFHB-VWNF0JOl08qKFgoprpynkKSuevUMN3dGZAlO84E842tkF5qq33N4KiJ8wiJTgHkc--jt~SDeSTVkGuHiZqQnTr599vq17zkVFab4xBF6Ui3TXz8y6UGzFSb8Xzxu-oLjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual learning: a building block with a shortcut connection (He et\u00a0al. 2015). The weight layers are the assemble of several convolutional layers and other necessary layers. Relu (Xavier et\u00a0al. 2011) is one kind of Activation Function.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983572/sty2708fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983572\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=QxwsolBxl1AesxI-Q9RP9UOtjBccABkZHsl-RxXOCdynB6WMrISgUTySrgc-CNP5WHQke28GlB6UgBPKo2VI5bkxKVlsCjjYlyNlenipMFAvPBuFuBmaEWqnp4an9A3dXVFDvg-yTQGNc7PLCGq0qDsTCK1PedX1kZlKGsDLwTYWeUpHXL6QW3-dNqsEkv1eADb~ULjndGl8q8TP0bt-L4ck5kga1RYWMxCFbmD0E-ZKJ~IYTtiJuwBzUe~VYBzMvd8vS-myCZZFA9jXu4zlEs~aB9N0K0ojXOVo6T4wLM3~7vsY84NM3bbD7pW4ktQHmz~Rg~MWBQzR9c9QjqHvaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983572&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual learning: a building block with a shortcut connection (He et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The weight layers are the assemble of several convolutional layers and other necessary layers. Relu (Xavier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is one kind of Activation Function.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our study, we use Machine Learning to find gravitational lens candidates based on spectroscopic selection. Spectrum is one-dimensional sequence that has local correlations. We use one-dimensional CNNs to build the Machine Learning model because CNNs have good performance in distinguishing the inputs with local correlations. In order to prevent the \u2018degradation\u2019 problem of deep networks and reduce the training difficulty, we adopt the ResNet model to our study. In fact, before the final choice of ResNet, we have tried several \u2018plain\u2019 networks (e.g. LeNet; AlexNet), but they are difficult to converge in our study.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=122983574 id=\"122983574\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 FIND EMISSION LINES WITH RESNET</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">So far, there are several gravitational lens surveys based on spectroscopic selection (e.g. the SLACS, BELLS, S4TM, and BELLS GALLERY). The SLACS, BELLS, and S4TM concentrated on searching for multiple emission lines (meanly the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 5007) from the galaxies with redshift higher than the foreground galaxies, while the BELLS GALLERY focused on only one Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> line. We put forward that Machine Learning could be used to search for galaxy-scale gravitational lens candidates based on spectroscopic selection. As the first application, in this study we use ResNet to find some galaxy-LAE lens candidates in the BOSS spectra by searching for high redshift (2 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 3) Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines in the spectra of middle redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span> \u223c 0.5) galaxies. However, in the band used in this work (3800\u2009\u00c5 &lt;\u03bb &lt; 5000\u2009\u00c5, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>), the spectra with lower redshift [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727 or other emission lines could also be found by our networks. We will abandon these spectra using several other subsequent selections (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983576 id=\"122983576\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 The BELLS GALLERY survey</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens candidates of BELLS GALLERY are selected from the DR12 of the BOSS by searching for Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines from high redshift LAEs, and then following up high-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging observations to confirm the lens nature. In Shu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), the first and most important step is selecting out the spectra with emission lines that are not from the target galaxies themselves. To do this, they confined their research to the observed wavelength range of 3600\u2009\u00c5 &lt;\u03bb &lt; 4800\u2009\u00c5 (roughly 2 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 3 for the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines) and used an error-weighted matched-filter with a Gaussian kernel to search for the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines in BOSS targets. This main step yielded 4982 hits. Then they performed several subsequent selections to reject the false hits and finally found 187 lens candidates with obvious Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines. They presented 21 high quality BELLS GALLERY candidates in their paper. Among them 17 candidates have been confirmed as strong gravitational lenses by <em>HST</em> imaging observations. The goal of the BELLS GALLERY survey is exploiting the small-scale dark sub-structure around ETGs and constraining the slope and normalization of the substructure-mass function (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">BELLS GALLERY is a successful lens candidates searching work. Whereas, the first step of the search is complex and consume too much time. First, they have to obtain the accurate spectral flux errors across the observed spectra. Secondly, they need to fit each spectrum with standard ETGs spectroscopic templates to obtain the galaxy-subtracted residual spectrum. For millions of targets, these procession would consume a lot of time. In order to increase the searching speed, we introduce ResNet to automatically select out the spectra with emission lines that are not from the targets themselves.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983579 id=\"122983579\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 The predictive data and the train/test data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We aim to use ResNet to search for galaxy-LAE lens candidates from the DR12 of BOSS of SDSS-\u2009III. At beginning, we need to filter out all the ETG spectra from the database to build our predictive data. The BOSS targets have been classified as several classes, such as \u2018GALAXY\u2019, \u2018SKY\u2019, \u2018STAR\u2019. Therefore, we can choose the \u2018GALAXY\u2019 class and reject the targets with sub-class of \u2018STARFORMING\u2019, \u2018BROADLINE\u2019, and \u2018AGN\u2019. We then select the target with redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 0.3. These selections result in 1\u00a0241\u00a0799 recorders. For these recorders, we only use the spectra from 3800\u2009\u00c5 to 5000\u2009\u00c5 to build our predictive spectra. Note that we do not use the same wavelength range as BELLS GALLERY (3600\u2009\u00c5 &lt;\u03bb &lt; 4800\u2009\u00c5), because the spectra in the wavelength from 3600\u00c5 to 3800\u2009\u00c5 is very noisy, which could decrease the accuracy of our ResNet model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our predictive data includes 177 known lens candidates from Shu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>). The remaining 10 candidates found in their work are eliminated because of the redshift limitation. Among the 177 candidates, there are 3 spectra with Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines falling out of the wavelength of 3800\u2009\u00c5 &lt;\u03bb &lt; 5000\u2009\u00c5. Therefore, only 174 candidates could be used to test our ResNet model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding lens candidates in a great deal of galaxy spectra is a classification problem. Therefore, we use ResNet to build a classifier which can select out the spectra with emission lines not from the foreground galaxies themselves. Then, we use several other subsequent selections similar with previous work to reject the false hits. The quality of the train/test data is critical for the accuracy of the classifier and directly affect the efficiency of the selection. For the train/test data, we require: (1) the train/test spectra are not in the DR12 of the BOSS of SDSS-\u2009III, but look similar as the spectra in the database; (2) the number of the train/test spectra has to be large enough, usually larger than 10\u00a0000; (3) the train/test spectra have been classified into two groups, one group has no Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines (labelled [0]), and the other has Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines (labelled [1]); 4\u3009 for the real spectra in DR12, the spectra with Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines are much less than the spectra without Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines, which makes the data imbalance. We need a similar data imbalance in the train/test data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">So far, there are no more than 200 galaxy spectra with Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines from high redshift, which is far from enough. Therefore, we use the following procedures to build an artificial train/test data set. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We grid the redshift to small bins (\u03b4<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 0.002\u00a05), and at each redshift bin we perform a principal component analysis (PCA) to the spectra of ETGs (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Then, we use the first six eigenvectors of the PCA to create some artificial galaxy spectra at the corresponding redshift. This procedure yields totally 150\u00a0000 artificial galaxy spectra.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We add the \u2018SKY\u2019 (from BOSS targets) and noise to the created spectra. Now the spectra look similar as real spectra. We then cut out the spectra ranged from 3800\u00c5 to 5000\u2009\u00c5.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the rest-frame wavelength, we create 10\u00a0000 artificial Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines using Gaussian profiles. The mean wavelength of the Gaussian profiles is at 1216\u2009\u00c5 and the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) is randomly obtained from a normal distribution with the mean value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$300\\, \\mathrm{km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> and standard deviation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$200\\, \\mathrm{km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. We then limit the FWHM greater than 0.5\u2009\u00c5 and the peak of the emission lines greater than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.5\\times 10^{-17}\\, \\mathrm{erg\\, cm^2\\, \\mathring{\\rm A} }^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. Finally, we randomly shift the emission lines to the wavelength of 3800\u2009\u00c5 &lt;\u03bb &lt; 5000\u2009\u00c5.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We randomly select 10\u00a0000 spectra from the 150\u00a0000 artificial spectra and add the 10\u00a0000 artificial Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines to them, then label them as [1]. The remaining spectra without emission lines are labelled as [0]. The above 1/15 selection is to overcome the data imbalance mentioned above.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Now, we have successfully created 150\u00a0000 train/test spectra. The PCA approach we performed in the first step could loss some information of the spectra. We point out that the lost information does not affect our training results. Because, first, the first 6 eigenvectors are enough to fit a real spectrum with an acceptable \u03c7<sup>2</sup>; secondly, most of the lost information is from noise, after adding the \u2018SKY\u2019 and noise in the second step, the created spectra look almost the same as real spectra. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> shows two high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) spectra with Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> emission lines. The left is the real spectrum of SDSS J1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 (one of BELLS GALLERY samples), the right is an artificial one with a synthetical Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> line. They look very similar. Another point need to be mentioned is the Gaussian profile approximations for creating Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines. As we will show in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, the Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines are in fact skewed. However, in this study, we just want to use ResNet to recognize the emission lines with any shapes. The shape judgement will be done by some other subsequent selections. Therefore, using skewed profiles to create Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines is not needed. During the experimental process, we can efficiently find the emission lines with any shapes using Gaussian profile approximations.</p>                        <a id=\"122983585\" scrollto-destination=\"122983585\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=j0ZbHnxwmR3b95wlXR4LlXVF6Ret0bNg0SlDyg-hgtrZ4DeZFMJywdTpNKyZKqEZxHfIvmBNYQ9V302b9Vl01~9fQLjg3ickvIS~ELeT7~RUX83zXTyKKxJAdkd7O08F8IpExsthv-bfc8wTTvdHBeBaDCrJK2XakMzvLwsuawS9XJyCgvuNv6b2yQB2PHFTxKE-0HjWkVfvci-kTBOaheKMrEa4jKlOJ3VHOmBQrM32Urmwr2PJ4WabXq4gfJK2IJ~TLtsNKUxZQfcIDBHWxevaCUxhnl3VWfSGW-ebZIe3oBGICJuFcAama95qdaBlMTKuwLplC~lRUHhWZSR5cA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The left is the spectrum of SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 from BELLS GALLERY. The right is an artificial one. Both have high SNR Ly\u00a0\u03b1 lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983585/sty2708fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983585\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=mT4w-qHbeavEk3F4FxPTVGhrNBzPoptHk6~v7cfptAZiisWk-MLsb6ie9DMhYHfqSS2feNBgZLTpR~PvC1vsU0soDWYbJxyMHHLScCrAQ49s3ApOo71DQrb1IuMDc311tVQm6~hMblNcfWTfDZcSnRz~sRA4a~-G6qYG0zrf6XtPNAB4GK3o3~-600zDPnGPo5WBEFZYvAMR2TR14a625gPvnFmKfiAQDJPu5DmeRYv0TFls6Oxvj~1h9JxLVqlluvweK12fymsuNiwwdSaxvec2Dif6IZtLEZ~ziowh94PiGDqzGpewjCvmHTiZlKqWBaTxPxAFQxmKDR66Pc-EoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983585&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The left is the spectrum of SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 from BELLS GALLERY. The right is an artificial one. Both have high SNR Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/m_sty2708fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&amp;Signature=j0ZbHnxwmR3b95wlXR4LlXVF6Ret0bNg0SlDyg-hgtrZ4DeZFMJywdTpNKyZKqEZxHfIvmBNYQ9V302b9Vl01~9fQLjg3ickvIS~ELeT7~RUX83zXTyKKxJAdkd7O08F8IpExsthv-bfc8wTTvdHBeBaDCrJK2XakMzvLwsuawS9XJyCgvuNv6b2yQB2PHFTxKE-0HjWkVfvci-kTBOaheKMrEa4jKlOJ3VHOmBQrM32Urmwr2PJ4WabXq4gfJK2IJ~TLtsNKUxZQfcIDBHWxevaCUxhnl3VWfSGW-ebZIe3oBGICJuFcAama95qdaBlMTKuwLplC~lRUHhWZSR5cA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The left is the spectrum of SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 from BELLS GALLERY. The right is an artificial one. Both have high SNR Ly\u00a0\u03b1 lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/122983585/sty2708fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"122983585\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/482/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2708/1/sty2708fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465557&Signature=mT4w-qHbeavEk3F4FxPTVGhrNBzPoptHk6~v7cfptAZiisWk-MLsb6ie9DMhYHfqSS2feNBgZLTpR~PvC1vsU0soDWYbJxyMHHLScCrAQ49s3ApOo71DQrb1IuMDc311tVQm6~hMblNcfWTfDZcSnRz~sRA4a~-G6qYG0zrf6XtPNAB4GK3o3~-600zDPnGPo5WBEFZYvAMR2TR14a625gPvnFmKfiAQDJPu5DmeRYv0TFls6Oxvj~1h9JxLVqlluvweK12fymsuNiwwdSaxvec2Dif6IZtLEZ~ziowh94PiGDqzGpewjCvmHTiZlKqWBaTxPxAFQxmKDR66Pc-EoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=122983585&ar=5116180&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2708fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The left is the spectrum of SDSSJ 1110\u00a0+\u00a02808 from BELLS GALLERY. The right is an artificial one. Both have high SNR Ly\u00a0<em>\u03b1</em> lines.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=122983586 id=\"122983586\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Our ResNet model</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Our ResNet model is implemented using the Keras with Tensorflow as its backend. Our model has 8 blocks, 28 convolutional layers, much deeper than plain CNNs. We add a \u2018max pooling\u2019 layer between any two blocks. A Dropout layer is employed before the fully connected layer to prevent overfitting. As mentioned before, the samples with label [1] are far less than the samples with label [0], making the data imbalance. Here, we also add another measurement \u2013 \u2018Focal Loss\u2019 \u2013 to overcome the effect of the data imbalance. The \u2018Focal Loss\u2019 can be written as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update99118_math1539109529255\" content-id=\"update99118_math1539109529255\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nL_{fl}= \\left\\lbrace\\begin{aligned} -(1-\\hat{y})^y {\\rm log} \\ \\hat{y} \\ \\ \\ \\ \\mathrm{ when}\\ y=1 \\\\\r\n-\\hat{y}^y{\\rm log}(1-\\hat{y}) \\ \\ \\ \\ \\mathrm{when}\\ y=0,\\\\\r\n\\end{aligned} \\right.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>y</em> \u2208 {0, 1} is the real label and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hat{y}$|</span> is the prediction value. The \u2018Focal Loss\u2019 is designed to improve the classification task with extreme data imbalance (Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then use the train/test data (train data/test data =\u00a09<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\colon$|</span>1) to train our ResNet model. In the training process, we mask the location of [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3347, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3427, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727, and [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3869 lines which may come from the ETGs themselves. The output of our model for each spectrum is the probability to be a lens candidate. We treat the samples with probabilities greater than 0.5 as lens candidates. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the accuracy and loss of the train/test data. We obtain a near-perfect test accuracy at 0.995\u00a04, the corresponding loss is 0.002\u00a08. Also, the completeness is 93.6\u00a0per\u2009cent. After successfully training, we apply the model to our predictive data (the emission lines of the ETGs also have been masked). We find all the 21 BELLS GALLERY lens candidates with the possibilities extremely close to 1. For all the 174 known lens candidates in our predictive spectra, we find 161. The discovery rate is 92.5\u00a0per\u2009cent. We do not call the discovery rate as completeness because the total number of the lens candidates in our predictive data are unknown.</p>                        <a id=\"122983589\" scrollto-destination=\"122983589\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img right is the corresponding loss.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\"
